title: How large might a human stone age tribe be? - Quora

response.answer_text: That's a great question. The Stone Age was a very long period with dramatically different levels of organization where there would be lots of variation based on how much food was available. In the early Stone Age, the size of a tribe was the source of their might. The human norm is to continuously push against your neighbors border. The bigger the tribe, the more territory it can hold. More territory has more food and can sustain more people. If a tribe can only sustain 30 members, they may only be able to maintain 5 fighting men. If the neighboring tribe has 10 fighting men, you are in serious trouble. That is why plains Indian tribes were so keen on adopting young captives. They really needed the people to maintain their border. The bison provided plenty to eat, so they were really just competing for hunting rights and prestige. Under these conditions they could probably sustain a group size of a couple hundred, but they were bands that cooperated in a federation. This was allowed because of their political organization. The whole tribe may have numbered in the few thousands to maybe low tens of thousands, but they had to stay spread out so they had sufficient resources. Agriculturalists, in my opinion, should probably not be lumped in the same group with true Stone Age people, but they could sustain as many people as their political system had resources to manage.

This gets a little technical. “Tribes” have a definition in anthropology that is more strict than the common use of the word assumes. An anthropological “tribe” has a name it applies to itself and its members. It generally also has a language that is shared among the members but is not spoken by neighbors. In California, the definition came under strain because throughout much of the state typical sociopolitical groups held many of the properties of “tribes” but were smaller in population and spoke languages shared shared to some degree with neighbors and did not hold a common name for themselves that was limited specifically to the social group. Kroeber was so frustrated that he coined the term “triblet” to apply specifically to many of the social groups. It simply means “small tribe.” California’s “stone age” tribelets ran to about 150 members maximum, and many had populations of half that. They were necessarily exogamous to a great degree because the close relationships. The Yokuts speaking peoples of the San Joaquin Valley and adjacent hills were the only “true” tribes in California and had populations that ran around 500 members. Small scale societies include “band level” societies that consist of very small groups of one or two nuclear families and maybe some older relatives. These groups coalesce (band together) annually or perhaps semi-annually for special purposes such as hunting big game moving in larger herds (buffalo, caribour, etc.) and to acquire spouses, trade, and hold ceremonies important to the entire band. Such organizations were common in the Great Basin, American Arctic and Australia.

Depends on which ‘Stone Age’ you are referring to: Old Stone Age, Middle Stone Age, or New Stone Age. It has been estimated that tribes living during the Old Stone Age, at least those inhabiting cave systems, probably numbered no more than 30 individuals (can’t crowd too many people into those caves, you know). Whereas, during the New Stone Age, urban communities arose due to the Agricultural Revolution, and populations of towns such as Jericho might be as high as 3,000; while the religious center of Çatal Hüyük might have contained as many as 10,000 at the height of its development.

Homo sapiens in the stone age depends upon the environment and food source. A “tribe” in the early stone age might consist of as little as one extended family unit two as many as five or six with a total tribe size ranging from 5 to 80. Each member would have to hunt/gather about 1200 calories of food each day, expending about that much in the process, so if the food supply allowed for more population, eventually fertility would rise to match while infertility and infant death would follow if the opposite is true.

Humans are just another animal, so based on that fact, I would say that the size of the community would depend on the availability of food in any given area. Plenty of flora & fauna for food will allow a community to grow in size, & for security, large is better than small.Keith.

Not very large at all simply because of their life style they were predominately hunter gathers accordingly they moved around a lot so its been estimated that not more than a few small groups were ever together for very long other than that the data is sketchy !!
